newsitem.title: GERMANY: New German futures contract gets warm reception.
newsitem.headline: New German futures contract gets warm reception.

text.p: Germany's electronic futures exchange DTB launched a new two-year debt futures contract on Friday to rave reviews from traders who see the product plugging a hole in the German futures yield curve.

Analysts said the contract, which is meant in part to improve Frankfurt's international financial standing, will quickly build liquidity because of increased trading of short dated instruments and a strong supply of underlying cash debt.
"I am firmly convinced this contract will be a success," said Timo Klein, analyst at MMS International in Frankfurt. "I can't see why investors won't take to it."

He and others said that within a couple of weeks, they see daily volume in the contract swelling to around 20,000 -- a level of liquidity sufficient to call the contract a success. Volume stood at around 8,400 on Friday afternoon.
The contract plugged what many considered a hole for futures trade on the German yield curve with contracts already available for 10-year, five-year, one-month and three-month euromark contracts.

"If successful, as we ultimately expect, this would create a futures market wich more fully covers the yield curve than any country in the world other than the U.S." Deutsche Morgan Grenfell wrote in a bond market comentary on Friday.

Analysts attribute part of their optimism to strong underlying supply for two-year cash debt. Lack of cash market supply crippled the DTB's efforts to offer a 30-year Bund future in the spring of 1994, forcing the contract to eventually be discontinued.
Bonn started issuing two-year notes in September 1996 and planned in the first quarter of this year to issue about 10 billion marks worth of the debt.
"The supply of two-year notes issues will help the futures contract," said Hans Nordstrom, trader at BMP Wertpapiere und Optionen GmbH.
Analysts also said the contract will gain interest in part because it is the only two-year bond futures contract in Europe.

The DTB said it hoped to ensure healthy volumes in the contract by naming six designated market makers who are obligated to continued price quotes and 17 designated brokers -- many of whom are foreign firms.
"The DTB is hoping that the international focus of these financial institutions will prove the impetus for a buoyant market in the new product," the DTB said in a statement.
From a volatility standpoint, however, the new contract starts at a difficult time.

Many economists expect the Bundesbank to keep interest rates on hold for some time, reducing swings in the short-end of the yield curve and giving investors less reason to want to hedge their holdings.
